Today we are learning about spending one-on-one time with our children. 

Spending dedicated time with your child will make them feel valued and loved.
It will also build trust and respect, and support their learning.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today we are learning to talk about feelings with our children. 

Recognising emotions in ourselves and our children is an important skill.

Talking about feelings helps our children learn to express and manage their emotions – even the difficult ones.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today’s lesson is about giving instructions that work!
How we give instructions matters – children are more likely to listen when we say what we want them to do, not what not to do.
Instead of “Don’t touch that!”, try: “Please only touch things that belong to us.”

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today’s topic is about helping your child learn and grow.

Play helps children learn what is expected and how to get along with others. It supports their development, both in school and at home.

This is true for all children, including those who are shy, have a disability, or struggle to keep up in class.

This is true for all children, including those who are shy, have a disability, or struggle to keep up in class.

text_1_facilitator.eng: @data.characters.f3_mother.name helped her son learn by playing together. Let’s explore how she did this.

text_2.eng:
@data.characters.f3_mother.name helped her son learn new skills by:
- ⚽ **Playing with him**: This let @data.characters.f3_son_4.name learn through doing. @data.characters.f3_mother.name didn’t need to show him how to build a house, he figured it out on his own.
- 🏆 **Letting him lead**: She allowed him to ask questions and explore. Curiosity helps children become confident and creative.
- 👏🏾 **Praising him**: She showed him that being curious and trying ideas is a good thing.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today’s lesson is about helping children follow rules and instructions by using consequences.

Consequences are the good or negative things that happen after a child’s actions. When children don’t follow a rule, giving consequences can help them learn and take responsibility for their actions.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today’s lesson is about helping children follow rules and instructions by using consequences.

Consequences are the good or negative things that happen after a child’s actions. When children don’t follow a rule, giving consequences can help them learn and take responsibility for their actions.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Some consequences happen naturally – like when a toy breaks, it can’t be used.

Others are set by you to help your child follow rules (_“if you don’t pack away your toys, you can’t play with them tomorrow”_). 

Let’s see how @data.characters.f1_father.name uses consequences to help his son, @data.characters.f1_son_5.name, follow instructions:

rows.text_1_facilitator:
I'M HUNGRY! HE HIT ME! I'M BORED!
Sound familiar? 

Every family faces challenges. Learning how to solve problems together with your child can help you when you have conflict in your home. 

It also teaches your children how to solve problems on their own. This will set them up for success throughout their life. What a gift!

text_1_facilitator.eng:
I'M HUNGRY! HE HIT ME! I'M BORED!
Sound familiar?

It also teaches your children how to solve problems on their own. This will set them up for success throughout their life. What a gift!

text_2.eng:
**In the next story, @data.characters.f2_grandfather.name and @data.characters.f2_son_8.name use four steps to solve a problem:**

1) 💡 KNOW IT: Talk to your child about what the problem is
2) 🔧 SOLVE IT: Think of possible solutions together
3) 🎯 TRY IT: Choose one solution to try
4) 💭 REFLECT: See if it worked. If not, try another solution

Today's topic is about taking care of yourself.

We often don’t look after ourselves enough. But this is so important, especially as a parent!

Reducing our stress and treating ourselves well helps us AND our teenagers.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today's topic is about spending one-on-one time with our teens. 

Being a parent can be so hard. Sometimes it feels like our teens never listen to us.

But science shows that spending just a few minutes each day of focused one-on-one time with your teen helps build trust and love.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today's topic is about spending one-on-one time with our teens. 

Being a parent can be so hard. Sometimes it feels like our teens never listen to us.

But science shows that spending just a few minutes each day of focused one-on-one time with your teen helps build trust and love.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Let's discuss, what is one-on-one time?

One-on-one time is when you focus on your teens, without distractions like TVs or phones. Let your teens take lead in choosing what you do or talk about.

It is great if you can spend fifteen minutes a day together, but even five minutes a day is really good.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Let's discuss, what is one-on-one time?

One-on-one time is when you focus on your teens, without distractions like TVs or phones. Let your teens take lead in choosing what you do or talk about.

It is great if you can spend fifteen minutes a day together, but even five minutes a day is really good.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Let's think of ways to spend time with your teen.

It may take some time to get used to one-on-one time, but the more you do it, the better it gets!

You are an amazing parent for trying this.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Let's think of ways to spend time with your teen.

It may take some time to get used to one-on-one time, but the more you do it, the better it gets!

You are an amazing parent for trying this.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Here are some skills to help guide you in spending one-on-one time with your teen!

text_1_facilitator.eng: Here are some skills to help guide you in spending one-on-one time with your teen!

rows.text_1_facilitator: Spending one-on-one time with your teen can be hard to plan. Here are some easy ideas that worked for other parents.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Spending one-on-one time with your teen can be hard to plan. Here are some easy ideas that worked for other parents.

text_2.eng:
**Ideas for one-on-one time with your teen:**
- Walk to the shops
- Play a game/sport
- Do a chore together
- Prepare dinner
- Eat breakfast/lunch/dinner
- Have tea after school
- Watch a TV show
- Review homework
- Chat before bedtime


**Remember to use your new skills:**
📅 **DAY**: try to do it every day,
⚽ **PLAY**: let your teen choose how to spend one-on-one time, and 
🎯 **STAY**: be focused on your teen!

rows.text_2:
**Ideas for one-on-one time with your teen:**
- Walk to the shops
- Play a game/sport
- Do a chore together
- Prepare dinner
- Eat breakfast/lunch/dinner
- Have tea after school
- Watch a TV show
- Review homework
- Chat before bedtime


**Remember to use your new skills:**
📅 **DAY**: try to do it every day,
⚽ **PLAY**: let your teen choose how to spend one-on-one time, and 
🎯 **STAY**: be focused on your teen!

Today's topic is about family budgets.

Many families are stressed about money, especially if teens keep asking for things!

When we make a budget together, we can agree how to spend AND save to prevent stress and work towards our family’s goals.

Today's topic is about family budgets.

Many families are stressed about money, especially if teens keep asking for things!

When we make a budget together, we can agree how to spend AND save to prevent stress and work towards our family’s goals.

rows.text_1_facilitator: When we involve our teens in budgeting, they learn to be responsible with money and work towards goals. That is something we all want for our teens, right?

text_1_facilitator.eng: When we involve our teens in budgeting, they learn to be responsible with money and work towards goals. That is something we all want for our teens, right?

rows.text_1_facilitator:
It can be hard to make ends meet every month. Many families have this problem!

Including @data.characters.f2_grandmother.name – let's have a look:

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Dealing with money challenges, like @data.characters.f2_grandmother.name's situation, is stressful. 

A family budget can help @data.characters.f2_grandmother.name - and YOU!

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Dealing with money challenges, like @data.characters.f2_grandmother.name's situation, is stressful. 

A family budget can help @data.characters.f2_grandmother.name - and YOU!

text_2.eng:
**There are four steps for doing a family budget:**

💭 Step 1: THINK 
🎯 Step 2: CHOOSE 
⚒️  Step 3: BUILD 
📋 Step 4: PLAN

rows.text_2:
**There are four steps for doing a family budget:**

💭 Step 1: THINK 
🎯 Step 2: CHOOSE 
⚒️  Step 3: BUILD 
📋 Step 4: PLAN

rows.text_1_facilitator:
**Step 1: THINK**
Think about what you spend money on each month.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
**Step 1: THINK**
Think about what you spend money on each month.

text_2.eng:
- Draw pictures of all the things that you and your family spend money on each month.
- Write next to each picture how much each thing costs each month (there is no need to share the numbers if you don’t want to).
- Add up how much money you have to spend each month.

rows.text_2:
- Draw pictures of all the things that you and your family spend money on each month.
- Write next to each picture how much each thing costs each month (there is no need to share the numbers if you don’t want to).
- Add up how much money you have to spend each month.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
**Step 2: CHOOSE**
Think about your needs and wants.
- WANT is something you can live without. 
- NEED is something you cannot live without.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
**Step 2: CHOOSE**
Think about your needs and wants.
- WANT is something you can live without. 
- NEED is something you cannot live without.

text_2.eng:
Look at your list of things you spend money on and choose:

- Which are NEEDS that you cannot live without? Why?
- Which are WANTS which are nice to have but not essential? Why?
- Which things could you try to spend less money on?

rows.text_2:
Look at your list of things you spend money on and choose:

- Which are NEEDS that you cannot live without? Why?
- Which are WANTS which are nice to have but not essential? Why?
- Which things could you try to spend less money on?

rows.text_1_facilitator:
**Step 3: BUILD**
Make a budget!

text_1_facilitator.eng:
**Step 3: BUILD**
Make a budget!

text_2.eng:
- Write down what your income is for the month.
- Take some stones or beans or anything with lots of bits - this is your income for the month. For example: If your income is R2000 and you have 20 beans, each bean is R100.
- Decide what you will spend on, and put the stones/objects on that image.

Not sure about your decisions? Having trouble deciding between "needs" and "wants"? That’s totally fine! This exercise will get easier with practice.

rows.text_2:
- Write down what your income is for the month.
- Take some stones or beans or anything with lots of bits - this is your income for the month. For example: If your income is R2000 and you have 20 beans, each bean is R100.
- Decide what you will spend on, and put the stones/objects on that image.

Not sure about your decisions? Having trouble deciding between "needs" and "wants"? That’s totally fine! This exercise will get easier with practice.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
**Step 4: PLAN**
Plan how you can save money, so you can deal with emergencies and realise your family goals!

text_1_facilitator.eng:
**Step 4: PLAN**
Plan how you can save money, so you can deal with emergencies and realise your family goals!

text_2.eng:
If you can save even a tiny amount for the future or emergency - it can make a big difference over time.

- Add a circle called “emergencies”.
- Add a circle called “family goals”.
- Now try to move your money around so you can save a bit every month for goals and emergencies.

rows.text_2:
If you can save even a tiny amount for the future or emergency - it can make a big difference over time.

- Add a circle called “family goals”.
- Now try to move your money around so you can save a bit every month for goals and emergencies.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
CONGRATULATIONS!!! 🎉 

You have made your budget! Remember to do this exercise again with your other family members - if you agree on a plan together it will make a huge difference!

Think of the advantages and disadvantages of each savings option.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
When we involve teens in budgeting, they learn important life skills, like understanding the difference between needs and wants.

Making a budget together also helps teens see that we all need to make hard choices sometimes, but that it helps us to have enough money at the end of the month - and to realise our goals!

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today's topic is about rules.

Rules help teens understand what is expected of them.

Teens are more likely to follow rules if you create the rules WITH your teen and praise them for it!

Today's topic is about rules.

rows.text_1_facilitator: When we make rules together, it shows our teens that rules are there to keep everyone safe and respected - not just to control them. Setting rules as a family helps build trust and responsibility for both teens and parents.

text_2.eng:

rows.text_2:
**Remember to use your skills for rule setting:**

🔎 Real rules: Agree on real rules that are clear and fair. For example, you could agree that everyone says where they are going before leaving the house.
🎉 Praise rules: Praise when rules are followed!

rows.text_1_facilitator: Clear, simple rules made together with your teen are not about control - they are about keeping them safe and building responsibility. When teens understand the reasons behind the rules, they are more likely to follow them.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Clear, simple rules made together with your teen are not about control - they are about keeping them safe and building responsibility. When teens understand the reasons behind the rules, they are more likely to follow them.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today's topic is about calm consequences.

Our actions have consequences. Some consequences happen naturally (“if you break something, you can’t use it anymore”). Other consequences we set as a family to motivate us to follow the rules (“if you come home late, you can’t go out with friends tomorrow”).

HOW you set and use consequences together matters.

Getting consequences right helps teens behave better and makes family life calmer.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today's topic is about calm consequences.

Our actions have consequences. Some consequences happen naturally (“if you break something, you can’t use it anymore”). Other consequences we set as a family to motivate us to follow the rules (“if you come home late, you can’t go out with friends tomorrow”).

HOW you set and use consequences together matters.

Getting consequences right helps teens behave better and makes family life calmer.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Calm consequences work best when they are fair, agreed on together, and followed through consistently - not in anger.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Calm consequences work best when they are fair, agreed on together, and followed through consistently - not in anger.

Luckily, there are ways to discipline without getting angry or using violence… and they work well!

Giving calm consequences is important because it helps teens learn from their actions and take responsibility for their choices.

Today's topic is about teen safety.

Teens can spend a lot of time outside the house or online, where it is harder for us to keep them safe.

Talking together about safe and unsafe places, and how to prevent problems, really helps!

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today's topic is about teen safety.

Teens can spend a lot of time outside the house or online, where it is harder for us to keep them safe.

Talking together about safe and unsafe places, and how to prevent problems, really helps!

rows.text_1_facilitator: Sometimes our teens know things about their environment that we might not realise - and by talking, we can learn how to support them better.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Sometimes our teens know things about their environment that we might not realise - and by talking, we can learn how to support them better.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
The most important way to help keep your teen safe is to make sure that they know they can talk to you about anything. 

You can also come up with a Safety Word - a simple word your teen can use to let you know they have a problem, without fear of you getting angry. 

Let's see how this worked for @data.characters.f1_mother.name and her daughter @data.characters.f1_daughter_16.name:

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Our topic today is staying safe.

To keep our teens safe, we need to understand their reality and the potential risky situations they can find themselves in.

We can help our teens know how to use their thoughts, voice, AND body in dangerous situations. It makes a big difference!

Our topic today is staying safe.

To keep our teens safe, we need to understand their reality and the potential risky situations they can find themselves in.

We can help our teens know how to use their thoughts, voice, AND body in dangerous situations. It makes a big difference!

rows.text_1_facilitator: Practising how to recognise warning signs and how to respond can help teens feel confident to protect themselves when it matters most.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Practising how to recognise warning signs and how to respond can help teens feel confident to protect themselves when it matters most.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
People can make us feel safe and happy—but sometimes they pressure us or make us uncomfortable. This can happen to both teens and adults.

Knowing the warning signs helps us stay safe.

Let’s look at some examples.

How could she use her voice to get away?

text_1_facilitator.eng:

Think about the moment when @data.characters.f2_daughter_19.name was pressured into a car.

How could she use her voice to get away?

text_2.eng:
**Find a chair and pretend it is the attacker. Practise saying/doing these responses:**

- 🔈 Yell: "No!" 
- 🆘 Call for help: "Someone help me!" 
- ⚠️ Warn of consequences: "I will call the police if you touch me again."
- ⛔ Name the behaviour: "Do not touch my bum.” or “Do not yell at me.”
- 😳 Act crazy: "Make a crazy scream or act like a gorilla!"
- 🚶🏾‍♀️ Pretend to go along to buy time: “I will do anything you want, just please don’t hurt me.”
- 🤡 Use humour: “No lift for me, thanks. Last time I got a lift I threw up EVERYWHERE!”
- 📱 Give something to get what you want: “I will give you my phone if you let me go.”

- ⛔ Name the behaviour: "Do not touch my bum.” or “Do not yell at me.”
- 😳 Act crazy: "Make a crazy scream or act like a gorilla!"
- 🚶🏾‍♀️ Pretend to go along to buy time: “I will do anything you want, just please don’t hurt me.”

text_2.eng:

⚠️ Spot warning signs: Talk with your teen about places, people, or situations that may not be safe. Remind them to trust their feelings.

Today's topic is about helping your teen learn.

Did you know that spending one-on-one time with your teen can help them do better at school? Today we will share some ideas to help you make the most of your time together.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today's topic is about helping your teen learn.

Did you know that spending one-on-one time with your teen can help them do better at school? Today we will share some ideas to help you make the most of your time together.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Learning does not only happen in school - it happens through fun activities, teamwork, and everyday moments. 
When we involve our teens and share decisions, we help them feel capable, confident, and connected to us.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Learning does not only happen in school - it happens through fun activities, teamwork, and everyday moments.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Caregivers and teens who spend time together often have happier, healthier relationships. But it is not always easy — sometimes we can both get angry, get annoyed and argue or fight.

Let’s take a look at an example:

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today’s topic is about creating rules and routines with our children.

When rules are part of a routine, they’re easier to follow. They help children understand what’s expected, take responsibility, and stay safe – all while making the home more calm and peaceful. And that’s something we all want, right?

Children are more likely to follow rules if you create them together.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today's topic is about problem solving. 

Every family faces challenges, but when we work together we can deal with problems in an effective and peaceful way.

What a great skill for your teen to learn too!

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today's topic is about problem solving. 

Every family faces challenges, but when we work together we can deal with problems in an effective and peaceful way.

What a great skill for your teen to learn too!

rows.text_1_facilitator:
As parents, we sometimes think we need to fix every problem by ourselves. And teens can think the same! 

By involving your teen, you strengthen your relationship as well as their confidence. Together you can overcome anything.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
When something bad happens, we often get upset and blame. But what our teens really need is someone to help find solutions together. 

Listen to them, accept how they see and feel things, and thank them for trusting you.

Teaching your teen how to deal with problems will help them for the rest of their lives. What a gift!

Listen to them, accept how they see and feel things, and thank them for trusting you.

Teaching your teen how to deal with problems will help them for the rest of their lives. What a gift!

text_2.eng:
**Here are some examples of problems other parents solved with their teens:**

- My teenager does not want to go to school
- I am worried my teenager will get pregnant or will get someone pregnant
- I am worried about what my teen does online
- My teenager is hanging out with bad friends
- My teenager is lazy
- My teenager is not doing their school work
- My teenager might be using drugs

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Yes, you may need to start the conversation - and it’s okay to feel shy. Be open and use the right words for any body parts you discuss (like breasts, penis, or vagina).

You can practise with a friend and ask a health worker or social worker for more information. The more you know, the better you can help your teen.

And remember, it’s also okay not to know everything. You can say, “I’m not sure - let me find out and tell you later.”

Yes, you may need to start the conversation - and it’s okay to feel shy. Be open and use the right words for any body parts you discuss (like breasts, penis, or vagina).

You can practise with a friend and ask a health worker or social worker for more information. The more you know, the better you can help your teen.

And remember, it’s also okay not to know everything. You can say, “I’m not sure - let me find out and tell you later.”

That’s not quite right.

Teens need to learn about body changes and relationships early, so they are prepared and can make good choices.

If you find out your teen is having sex, try to stay calm and share your worries gently. Getting angry can make it harder for your teen to talk to you.

Age 10 is when a lot of children start to enter puberty, so they need to already understand how their bodies and feelings may change.

This will also help them cope better with sexual feelings safely.

You don’t need to explain everything. Just give simple, honest answers that match their age and understanding.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
This may not work.

When we try to control too much, teens may do the opposite of what we want.

But when we guide them and give them space to make choices, they often act more responsibly.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
This may not work.

When we try to control too much, teens may do the opposite of what we want.

But when we guide them and give them space to make choices, they often act more responsibly.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
This may not work. 

Teens get pressure and information from many places we can’t control.

As parents, we can guide and prepare them to know what is right or wrong—and help them feel confident to make good decisions.

This may not work.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
That’s right.

When your teen feels trusted, they are more likely to trust you and come to you for advice or help.

Praise and thank them when they share. Avoid judging, so they feel safe to talk to you again.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
That’s right.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
That’s right.

Good decisions come from thinking through the consequences. Talk openly with your teen when there’s a problem. Listen to each other and find solutions together.

Each challenge is an opportunity to teach your teen that actions have consequences—and you can handle them as a team.

Remember to praise each other for working through tough situations together.

That’s right.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
That’s right.

To stay safe, your teen needs to know the difference between respectful behaviours and relationships, and unhealthy ones..

Respectful relationships feel caring, safe, and fair. Unhealthy ones involve pressure, discomfort, or feeling unsafe.

No one should be forced to do something they’re not okay with. You can learn more about this in the Staying Safe module.

That’s right.

rows.text_2: Another common question among parents:

text_2.eng: Another common question among parents:

rows.text_1_facilitator:
That’s not quite right.

Teens hear many things about sex—from school, friends, or social media. Some of it is wrong.

Knowing about sex doesn’t mean they are having sex. Good information helps them stay safe and understand why waiting to have sex can be a good choice.

Without this knowledge, they may face problems, like not knowing how pregnancy happens or the risks of sex.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
That’s not quite right.

Teens hear many things about sex—from school, friends, or social media. Some of it is wrong.

Knowing about sex doesn’t mean they are having sex. Good information helps them stay safe and understand why waiting to have sex can be a good choice.

Without this knowledge, they may face problems, like not knowing how pregnancy happens or the risks of sex.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
That’s not quite right.

Your teen might have a boyfriend or girlfriend and not tell you.

If you make them hide it, they may not come to you with questions or problems—and this can lead to risky situations.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
That’s not quite right.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
That’s right.

Teens are figuring out who they are. They look to friends and media for answers, and may feel pressure to do things they’re not ready for.

Talk calmly with your teen about waiting to have sex until they feel ready, are in a safe relationship, and understand the consequences. Focus on guiding them calmly to make healthy choices.

That’s right.

rows.text_1_facilitator:

Here are some skills to help you get started.

Here are some skills to help you get started.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
This week’s home activity is to read and talk about this module’s stories with your teen. Use them to start a conversation about body changes and relationships.

You can talk about what happened with @data.characters.f2_daughter_19.name or @data.characters.f1_daughter_16.name and their parents.

These stories can make it easier to talk about tricky topics and share ideas about healthy, respectful relationships.

Talking openly with your teen about body changes and relationships helps them feel safe, supported, and better able to make healthy choices. 

No matter your teen’s age, now is the best time to build trust and guide them with care.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today's topic is about managing stress.

We know how stressful it is to bring up teenagers in these times. Learning to manage your stress helps you – and your family.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today's topic is about managing stress.

We know how stressful it is to bring up teenagers in these times. Learning to manage your stress helps you – and your family.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
With a few small changes, you can feel more peaceful in your normal day-to-day life.

When you are peaceful, your family members will get calmer too!

text_1_facilitator.eng:
With a few small changes, you can feel more peaceful in your normal day-to-day life.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Having a Safety Word can help your teen stay safe too. You can choose any word as a Safety Word. Only your family knows it means ‘help’.

Your teen can say this word to let you know they are in trouble without you getting angry or punishing them, so you can help them.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Having a Safety Word can help your teen stay safe too. You can choose any word as a Safety Word. Only your family knows it means ‘help’.

Your teen can say this word to let you know they are in trouble without you getting angry or punishing them, so you can help them.

text_2.eng:
**What Safety Word can you choose with your teen? Here are some ideas from other families:**

🥑 A specific food
👵🏽 A specific family member
🐒 A specific animal
🤔 Something else

rows.text_1_facilitator: Here are a few skills to help you manage stress that you can use with your teens!

text_1_facilitator.eng: Here are a few skills to help you manage stress that you can use with your teens!

rows.text_1_facilitator:
There are two home activities for this week:

1) Whenever you are feeling stressed or upset with your teen, take five breaths in and out before you react.
And when you're both calm, share with each other how you feel. 

2) Choose a "Safety Word" with your teen, and think of a situation together when you could use this.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
There are two home activities for this week:

1) Whenever you are feeling stressed or upset with your teen, take five breaths in and out before you react.
And when you're both calm, share with each other how you feel. 

2) Choose a "Safety Word" with your teen, and think of a situation together when you could use this.

text_2.eng:
**Remember to:** 

😮‍💨 BREATHE: take five breaths in and out before you react
🤝🏾 SHARE: when you're both calm, share with your teen how you feel
💙 SHOW: ask them how they feel to show you care
🔍 SEEK: find something positive in this situation together

rows.text_1_facilitator: Remember, when we practice responding calmly and sharing how we feel, our teens learn to do the same. This skill will help them their whole life!

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Teens spend a lot of time online for fun, learning, and connecting with friends. The internet is full of opportunities, but also risks. 

As parents, we don’t have to understand every new app or game. What matters most is building a trusting relationship so teens feel safe to share. That way, we can help our teens stay safe by guiding, protecting, and exploring together.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Teens spend a lot of time online for fun, learning, and connecting with friends. The internet is full of opportunities, but also risks. 

As parents, we don’t have to understand every new app or game. What matters most is building a trusting relationship so teens feel safe to share. That way, we can help our teens stay safe by guiding, protecting, and exploring together.

rows.text_1_facilitator: When we explore the online world together, we understand our teens better. It shows our teens that staying safe online is about support and trust, not punishment or control. Learning simple safety steps as a family builds confidence and helps teens make better choices.

text_1_facilitator.eng: When we explore the online world together, we understand our teens better. It shows our teens that staying safe online is about support and trust, not punishment or control. Learning simple safety steps as a family builds confidence and helps teens make better choices.

rows.text_1_facilitator: For teens, the online world feels just as real and important as the offline world.

text_1_facilitator.eng: For teens, the online world feels just as real and important as the offline world.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Talking about online safety can feel hard. Many parents don’t know how to begin. A good start is to show interest in what your teen enjoys online. Let’s see how Sabelo’s mother does this…

text_1_facilitator.eng: Talking about online safety can feel hard. Many parents don’t know how to begin. A good start is to show interest in what your teen enjoys online. Let’s see how Sabelo’s mother does this…

text_2.eng: @data.characters.f1_mother.name sits next to her son while he is watching TikTok videos on the couch.

rows.text_2: @data.characters.f1_mother.name sits next to her son while he is watching TikTok videos on the couch.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
We saw how Sabelo and his mother talked openly about his time online.
Being online can help teens learn, create, and connect — but we also need to guide them to stay safe and use it wisely.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
We saw how Sabelo and his mother talked openly about his time online.
Being online can help teens learn, create, and connect — but we also need to guide them to stay safe and use it wisely.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Sometimes teens run into tricky or even dangerous situations online, and as parents it’s not always easy to know what to do.

Let’s look at 5 examples of online warning signs and talk about what warning signs to watch out for and how we can support our teens.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Sometimes teens run into tricky or even dangerous situations online, and as parents it’s not always easy to know what to do.

Let’s look at 5 examples of online warning signs and talk about what warning signs to watch out for and how we can support our teens.

text_2.eng: **Warning Sign 1: Lerato is quiet and withdrawn — a change in mood can signal something is wrong.**

rows.text_2: **Warning Sign 1: Lerato is quiet and withdrawn — a change in mood can signal something is wrong.**
**Warning Sign 2: Thandeka hears about a classmate sharing private photos — hearing such stories is a warning sign to talk with your teen about pressure and safety online.**

text_2.eng: **Warning Sign 2: Thandeka hears about a classmate sharing private photos — hearing such stories is a warning sign to talk with your teen about pressure and safety online.**

rows.text_2:
**Warning Sign 3:Sizwe is being threatened online — fear and threats are warning signs of sextortion or blackmail.** 
He receives a phone message: “Send me another picture or I’ll share the last one with your family and friends…”

text_2.eng:
**Warning Sign 3:Sizwe is being threatened online — fear and threats are warning signs of sextortion or blackmail.** 
He receives a phone message: “Send me another picture or I’ll share the last one with your family and friends…”

rows.text_2: **Warning Sign 4: A boy shared private pictures at school — sharing or showing harmful images is a warning sign that teens need clear guidance.**

text_2.eng: **Warning Sign 4: A boy shared private pictures at school — sharing or showing harmful images is a warning sign that teens need clear guidance.**

rows.text_2:
**Warning Sign 5: Luks got a message from a stranger in his game — when strangers offer gifts or ask to chat, it’s a warning sign of danger.**
Luks is showing his grandfather how he is playing the game he loves on his phone. Suddenly a message pops up:

Stranger in game: “I saw your profile. We are at the same school! Let’s chat privately, I’ll send you data.”

text_2.eng:
**Warning Sign 5: Luks got a message from a stranger in his game — when strangers offer gifts or ask to chat, it’s a warning sign of danger.**
Luks is showing his grandfather how he is playing the game he loves on his phone. Suddenly a message pops up:

Stranger in game: “I saw your profile. We are at the same school! Let’s chat privately, I’ll send you data.”

rows.text_1_facilitator: Keeping your teen safe online starts with understanding their experiences. Let’s come up with easy ways to get involved in your teen’s world online.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Keeping your teen safe online starts with understanding their experiences. Let’s come up with easy ways to get involved in your teen’s world online.

text_2.eng:
**Here are some examples of shared online moments:**

🖥️ Watch a short video or song together
💜Share memes and funny videos
🤡Ask your teen to teach you something online (for example, helping with posting a family photo)
💬Ask “Did you see anything exciting or interesting online today?” 
📓Help them with homework online

rows.text_1_facilitator: Here are some tips to help you with online safety:

text_1_facilitator.eng: Here are some tips to help you with online safety:

rows.text_1_facilitator:
This week’s activity: make your own Online Family Agreement with your teen. 👨‍👩‍👧‍👦

When you create rules together, teens feel part of the team—not controlled—and are more likely to follow them.

Sit with your teen and write 5 rules for safe and fun online time. Put them on the wall when done. Involve both mom and dad to show that everyone helps keep the family safe.

Here’s an example:

text_1_facilitator.eng:
This week’s activity: make your own Online Family Agreement with your teen. 👨‍👩‍👧‍👦

When you create rules together, teens feel part of the team—not controlled—and are more likely to follow them.

Sit with your teen and write 5 rules for safe and fun online time. Put them on the wall when done. Involve both mom and dad to show that everyone helps keep the family safe.

Here’s an example:

text_2.eng:
**Online Family Agreement (example)**

Our family agrees to these rules for safe and fun online time:
🔑 Keep accounts private
🚩 Do not share school, address, or phone number
✅ Ask permission before sharing photos of others
⏰ No phones during meals or at bedtime
☀️ Be kind and respectful to others online
😃 Share one positive or funny post or video with the family each week
💛 Teens: I will talk to an adult if anything feels wrong or uncomfortable online
✨ Parents: I will listen and support my teens without judging or blaming

Signed by:
🔶 Parent / caregiver __________
🔷 Teen __________

rows.text_2:
**Online Family Agreement (example)**

Our family agrees to these rules for safe and fun online time:
🔑 Keep accounts private
🚩 Do not share school, address, or phone number
✅ Ask permission before sharing photos of others
⏰ No phones during meals or at bedtime
☀️ Be kind and respectful to others online
😃 Share one positive or funny post or video with the family each week
💛 Teens: I will talk to an adult if anything feels wrong or uncomfortable online
✨ Parents: I will listen and support my teens without judging or blaming

Signed by:
🔶 Parent / caregiver __________
🔷 Teen __________

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Online risks can look different for boys and girls. They may hide or act out in different ways. When we blame or punish, they stop sharing — and the risk grows.

You don’t need to know everything. The best way to keep your teen safe is to build trust, stay calm, and let them know they can always come to you for help.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Online risks can look different for boys and girls. They may hide or act out in different ways. When we blame or punish, they stop sharing — and the risk grows.

You don’t need to know everything. The best way to keep your teen safe is to build trust, stay calm, and let them know they can always come to you for help.
